coredata.dc:title: X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) studies of the distribution of low-lying unoccupied states in PdCl2
coredata.dc:creator: Sham, T.K.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
L edge absorption spectra of PdCl2 have been obtained with synchrotron radiation. These results are compared with those of Pd metal. It is found that their near edge structure can be understood qualitatively on the basis of dipole transition and the conventional description of bonding in these systems.

Introduction The absorption features in the edge jump region of an X-ray absorption spectrum, now commonly known as the X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES). has recently received considerable attention. XANES refers to the early portion of the X-ray absorption spectrum and contains absorption features below and ==60 eV above the ionization threshold of an edge in contrast to the extended X-ray absorption fine struc- ture (EXAFS) which extends to as much as 1000 eV above the threshold- Absorption below the threshold primarily arises from bound state to bound state di- pole transitions and often exhibits sharp resonances (sometimes called white lines) [1^]. Absorption slight- ly above the threshold involves transitions to upper final states and can be very complicated because these final states are only slightly above the vacuum level and can be easily influenced by a slight modification of the potential of the absorbing atom (such as the presence ofligands and the creation of the core hole). Shape resonance in molecules [3,4] in the gas phase and transitions to higher bands in metals [5] often occur in this region. The main concern in this study however is the absorption below the ionization thresh- old and its relationship to bonding- The origin of the absorption feature below the threshold in the near edge region has been reasonably well understood for transition metals and their com- pounds [1,2]. The distribution of the density of the low-lying unoccupied states and dipole selection rules are responsible for the presence or absence of white lines [1 12] although quantitative agreement be- tween ground state calculation and experiment cannot always be obtained [12]. The basic principles of this absorption process have been discussed by Brown [2] and by Brown et al. [1] on the basis of a single-particle approximation. More recently, both theory and experi- ment have given strong support to this density of state picture. For example, Mattheiss et al. [6] have carried out detailed relativistic band calculations for Pt and Au. They show that the Lo^ edge features in Pt and Au are indeed related to the distribution of the unoc- cupied density of d states. Kutzler et al. [4] using the Xo- SW technique [7] have been able to reproduce the near edge structure in certain high-symmetry complexes rather successfully. Horsley [8], using the same tech- nique but combining quantitatively both L^ and 3 edge results in the inte--pretation, has deduced the number of d holes in a series of Pt and Ir compounds and has used these numbers to establish sensible chem- ical trends. Balzarotti et al- [9] have demonstrated that for titanium metal and its carbides and nitrides, the local partial density of states at the metal site is adequate to describe the XANES. It has also been shown that for a series of elements across the periodic table, the change of the near edge absorption features from noble metals to main group metals to halogen ion and to alkaline metal ion is entirely consistent with the filling of the corresponding s, p, and d states [10]. Under favorable conditions, the crystal field splitting has also been studied [11]. The objective of this work - 0 009-2614/83/0000-OOOO/S 03.00 1983 North-Holland 567 Volume 101, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 November 1983 is to study the relationship between near edge struc- ture and tlie distribution of the density of unoccupied slates in PdCl^. These results are also compared with those ofPd metal. PdC^ is cliosen for several reasons, first the oxida- tion state of the Pd site in PdCl^ is formally Pd(II), this assures the presence of low-lying unoccupied d states; second, the local symmetry of PdCl^ + is D^ so that the symmetry of the unoccupied molecular orbitais can be established in tlie crystal field approx- imation: third, experimentally, the binding energies of the L shell ofPd are 3.2-3.6 keV. Tlie intrinsic lifetime of these L core holes are long enough for meaningful measurements of the width of the white lines. These widths are relevant to the distribution of the density of unoccupied states. Finally, it is inter- esting to note that PdCl- is a very important catalytic component in tlie industrial Wacker process in which monoolelins are convened to corresponding aldehydes or ketones. 2- Experimental results and discussion X-ray absorption spectra were recorded at SSRL using tlie 11-3 beam line which was equipped with a focusing mirror and a double crystal monoclironiator (Si(l 11)). [14] have recently compared experimental L edge results of rare earth metals with accurate single- particle band structure calculation over a range of 100 eV above tlie threshold and show that the one-electron theory describes the XANES reasonably well. Kutzler et al. [15] have also studied the white lines oflanthanide complexes and found that they correspond to a core to d-like bound state transition. It may first appear surprising that there is little chem- ical shift between the white lines ofPd metal and PdCl- . Similar observation has been reported by Bianconi et al. [16]. They found no chemical shift between the L edge white lines of Pd and PdO samples supported on Si0-> substrates while the XPS 3d core level binding energy shift between these two samples was 1.7 eV. Several factors need to be considered before we can interpret the L edge wliite line chemical shifts. These factors are: the ground state chemical shift of the atomic-like core level; the shift of the position of the valence d states relative to the vacuum level upon compound forma- tion; and finally the pulling down of the d state involved in the transition by the creation of the 2p core hole. Considering the oxidation state of the Pd atom m these systems it is expected that the atomic-like 2p core level 570 Volume 101- number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 November 1983 in PdCl7 should be more tightly bound than that in Pd metal- For chemically active d states (4d in Pd) how- ever, the situation between PdCl->, an insulator and Pd, a metal is different. In Pd metal, a high density of un- occupied d states concentrates just above the Fermi level which is only ==4-5 eV below the vacuum level. Thus the ionization threshold is wt-S eV above the ris- ing edge of the white line. In PdCl^, the unoccupied Pd d states are considerably tighter bound than those in the metal. If we only consider the first two peaks in the 1,3 edge spectra of PdCl- as the features arising from bound state to bound state transitions (an under- estimate), the lower bound of the ionization threshold, "(h has to be at least 10 eV above the edge as shown in fig. 2- It must be the effect of the local bonding that sliifts tlie d states in PdCl-? down to compensate the ground state core level shift (with respect to vacuum). The pulling down of the valence states upon core hole creation is a well-known phenomenon [17]- It is reason- able to conjecture that a more localized unoccupied valence state (metal center MO) may be more suscep- tible to the influence of the core hole than a delocal- ized unoccupied state (d band). This effect sliould furtlier compensate the ground state shift of the core levels. The magnitude of this relaxation shift for these transitions is not well known but tlie difference of this relaxation shift is not expected to be greater than tlie ground state chemical shift due to bonding. What emerges from the above discussion is that the ground state binding energy shift of the unoccupied valence d states and relaxation compensate tlie expected ground state binding energy shift of the Pd p shell between PdCl^ and Pd metal. It is the ionization threshold that is a relevant parameter for binding energy comparison (analogous to XPS binding energy shift). Ionization thresholds for PdCl^ are clearly at higher energy ( =4 eV, fig. 2) than those for Pd metal. The comparison of the widtli of the white lines be- tween PdCl^ and Pd metal however has significant meaning. The width at half maximum of the white line between these compounds differs by >1.0 eV with the PdCl^ width being narrower. The PdCl-? white line is also more symmetric than the white line of the metal. The above observations are expected on the basis of ground state bandwidths when comparing a somewhat localized unoccupied MO in a compound (see footnote in section 1) with the dispersive d band in a metal. These results clearly demonstrate the sensitivity and usefulness of the XANES tecluuque in studying the energy distribution of the density of unoccupied states. The ground state width of tlie unoccupied portion of the d band at tlie Fermi level in Pd is =0.5 eV. A crude estimate shows that the ground state widtli of tlie low- lying unoccupied l>Jg(d 2 2) is ^0.3 eV. This width comes about from vibronic coupling and extended interaction (energy bands) of the PdC^ unit in PdCl^ crystal. It is interesting to note that while the L.2 3 edge wliite lines of PdCl7 appear at the same plioton energy as tliose ofPd metal, tlie rising edge of the PdCl^ Lj spectrum shifts to higher energy by 4 eV. Conclusions The L edge XANES results ofPdCl^ and Pd metal clearly show that PdCl-> has higher and narrower den- sity of unoccupied states than Pd metal as expected and that this technique can be used to probe the low- lying unoccupied states. The near edge structures in both materials are in qualitative accord with tlie con- ventional bonding descriptions; they are indeed related to tlie nature and distribution of tlie unoccupied states- However, detailed assignment of the entire absorption spectrum awaits more elaborate considerations of the excitonic and band nature of the final states as well as * The L edge jumps are at 3173, 3330 and 3605 eV. 571 Volume 101. number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 November 1983 multielectron processes.
